results.title: Feel like going home
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”, “Feel like going home” is Scorsese’s own directorial contribution, tracing the blues from the Mississippi Delta back to its roots in the Niger River, Mali. Musician Corey Harris acts as a guide along the journey, conducting interviews with a variety of musicians and engaging in song with several. Whilst examining the musical milieu of the Mississippi Delta, Scorsese addresses the work of Alan Lomax, the pioneering musicologist who recorded innumerable obscure American musicians and singers. Presents brilliant vintage footage of early blues men, such as Son House and John Lee Hooker whilst painting a picture of the rural poverty that dominated the lives of these future greats. Original performances include Willie King, Corey Harris, Taj Mahal, Keb Mo, Otha Turner, Habib Koite, Salif Keita, and Ali Farke Toure.

results.title: Feeding and clothing China's millions
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Dennis Sawyer and Andy Thomson
results.brief_description: This exotic film provides a detailed picture of a very different culture, a cooperative and conserver society of the North China plain. Life here revolves around agriculture—wheat, rice and cotton crops—and almost everyone is involved in their intense cultivation. A cotton factory in an industrial city reveals another link in China’s massive, coordinated efforts to ensure its people adequate food, clothing, shelter and jobs.

results.title: Feeding
results.creator_credit: Chris Farrell, Norman Athersmith, Margot Phillipson and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Five 10 minute programs as screened on ABC television giving advice for parents on the feeding of young children. Discusses breast and bottle feeding, weaning, the introduction of solid foods and general aspects of nutrition.

results.title: Feed them to the cannibals!
results.creator_credit: Dangerous to Know, Baobab Productions and Fiona Cunningham Reid
results.brief_description: In 1972 a small number of lesbians and gay men held the first Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras in Sydney, a then militant solidarity march for gay rights. Over the last two decades the Sydney Gay Mardi Gras has become one of the biggest festivals around the world, attracting hundreds of thousands of international and domestic tourists every year. The film explores the history of the Sydney lesbian and gay community, a community organised around relationships of love, solidarity and pleasure and which is challenging the traditional ways society has understood family, love and commitment. Many of the activists interviewed discuss the changes in gay and lesbian politics over the last twenty years and the changes in the lived experiences of non-heterosexuality.

results.title: Federation Square time lapse project
results.brief_description: Time lapse footage of the construction of the Federation Square site. Includes hourly photos take from the architect’s office, commencing April 1998. Intended to be used for a short animation sequence.
results.description: Time lapse footage of the construction of the Federation Square site. Includes hourly photos take from the architect’s office, commencing April 1998. Intended to be used for a short animation sequence.

results.title: Federation films: Australian films from early 20th century
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and Chris Long
results.brief_description: This is not only a documentary of moving image history in Australia prior to and on Federation, but also a tribute to the early pioneers of the motion picture industry. Discusses the role of the Salvation Army as the largest film making body during the earlier part of this century and provides short histories of our early cameras and their operators. Highlights include The Federation Parade, scenes from the Boer War and documentaries representing Australia as part of a “Greater Britain”. These early film pieces are superbly restored.

results.title: Federation
results.creator_credit: Anna Grieve, Film Australia and Ian Munro
results.brief_description: The story of Federation is an epic tale of Australia. This three part journey to nationhood looks at the land, the people, and the nation, recounting stories of the founding fathers and of the people from six separate colonies during the decades preceding Federation. The story depicts a struggle to create an Australian democracy which occurred as a result of the federation of Australian colonies in 1901. It does not glorify events or characters or avoid the more sensitive or troublesome facts of our past. It faces the hard issues of who was excluded from the rights and privileges of Australian citizenship, and thus includes the voices of women and Indigenous people who were largely ignored at the time. The tale is one of victory and loss, success, resistance and debate, and of the struggle not just to make an Australian nation, but to create a democracy. Written by Sue Castrique and narrated by John Doyle (Roy Slaven). The story is presented in 3 episodes: The Land, The People, The Nation, although each episode can stand alone.
